awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Developing Service-Learning Course-based Undergraduate Research Experiences to Increase Student Interest in Research by Targeting Communal Goals
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to serve the national interest by increasing the diversity of the STEM workforce of the United States. To do so, the project proposes to increase students’ perception of, interest in, and motivation to pursue research careers. Research studies have shown that students, particularly women, students from historically underserved groups, and first-generation students, often value communal goals of working together and helping people.  Consequently, the project proposes to create innovative undergraduate courses in which students not only perform STEM research but also apply their research work to directly serve their communities. This combination of research and service learning has the potential to transform students’ ideas about research, including the capacity of research to help people.  In addition, it can also empower the communities with whom the students work.

We propose to combine two high-impact practices, service learning and research experiences, to create a Service-Learning theme within a Course-Based Undergraduate Research Experience (SL-CURE).  This SL-CURE will be implemented in three different institutions: (1) a large, public, historically black university; (2) a small, private, predominantly white liberal arts college; and (3) a large, public Hispanic serving institution in the context of multiple disciplines (biology, public health, social work). Assessing the impact of the SL-CURE will be grounded in the theory of the transtheoretical stages of change from pre-contemplation (when students don’t consider research as a potential career) through preparation (when students develop scientific skills and a broader, more realistic perspective of research affordance of communal goals). The project will also contribute to the STEM education community by assessing how specific implementations of service-learning, including community-based participatory research, science communication and outreach, and mentoring, influence students’ perceptions of, interest in, and engagement in research practices not only during the course, but also one to two years beyond course completion. Disseminating this model is expected to influence existing and future CURES, which may result in a strong positive impact on retaining diverse individuals in the STEM workforce pipeline. This project is supported by the NSF Improving Undergraduate STEM Education Program: Education and Human Resources.   The IUSE: EHR program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students. This project is in the Engaged Student Learning track, through which the program supports the creation, exploration, and implementation of promising practices and tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
​​Rationale/hypothesis: There is significant disparity between STEM workforce demographics and the diversity of the United States as historically underserved populations remain underrepresented in the scientific and technological workforce. One potential cause of this disparity is a discrepancy between the students' perception of the goals attainable through research and their own personal and professional goals. This inconsistency potentially originates from misconceptions of the scientific endeavor, often misrepresented as individualistic and detached from community issues. In an effort to illustrate how scientific inquiry can serve communal as well as agentic (individualistic) goals, we designed a courses that combined two high-impact practices at multiple institutions:

●  Service learning (SL) - an educational approach that integrates community engagement with academic coursework allowing students to apply classroom knowledge to real world challenges while reciprocally benefiting the community, promoting hands-on learning and civic responsibility.

●  Course based Undergraduate research Experiences (CUREs)-  educational programs that integrate authentic research activities into undergraduate coursework. Unlike traditional labs with known outcomes, CUREs engage students in authentic research, allowing them to contribute to scientific discovery.

We hypothesized that combining service learning with course-based undergraduate research experiences (SL-CUREs) would enhance underrepresented students' interest in STEM by changing students’ perceptions of careers in STEM research as a way to achieve both their communal and agentic goals. 

Methodology:  Working at diverse institutions ranging from large public minority serving universities to small, private colleges, we designed courses where students participated in authentic research. The CURE projects varied between institutions, including: (1) the collection and characterization of plants and invertebrate species in restoration sites, (2) the isolation of new antibiotic-producing soil bacteria, (3) analysis of water quality in residential homes, (4) assessment of the impact of mobile food markets on health and behavior of individuals in regions designated as food deserts, and (5) molecular genetics analysis of ecologically important gopher tortoises. In conjunction with some of these CUREs, we incorporated service learning, where students engaged in civic projects related to the research studies. These included: (1) Ecological restoration service, (2) work with food distribution centers and mobile markets to serve food insecure communities, (3) Educational programming on water quality for North Carolina middle/high schools. In order to assess the impact of SL-CURES on student perceptions and career goals, we collected and analyzed a combination of both quantitative and qualitative data from Pre and Post assessment surveys (goal orientation and goal affordance) as well as short (21) and long-term (29) interviews.

Intellectual Merit: We observed unexpected results in goal orientation across student groups who varied in their communal and agentic goals. Although all students hold both communal and agentic goal orientations, those hailing from minoritized groups hold more communal-oriented goals. Given the discrepancies between our data and the current literature regarding goal orientation, we developed a new assessment tool: Goal Affordance Priority Sorting Exercise (GAPSE). This innovative tool uses a venn diagram format where students sort goals into categories that reflect either their personal importance, their alignment with research, or both. This tool provides insight into the motivations and perceptions of students, particularly students from underserved communities who may view research careers as less aligned with their communal goals. Researchers and educators can use this tool to develop interventions that target misconceptions about research as well as to help highlight types of research that can help students fulfill personal goals, thus removing a barrier for minoritized individuals entering research. Most existing analyses of CUREs analyze within course changes. Our long-term interviews revealed that both CURE and SL-CURE courses increased students’ interest in research and inspired future engagement in additional research-based courses and independent research experiences, partly because students were exposed to a variety of research topics that expanded their view of what research is and how research can solve problems. These insights inform the construction of more equitable learning environments that can promote the academic success of all STEM students. 

Broader Impact: Our project provided students from underrepresented backgrounds with meaningful research and service-learning experiences.  In addition, the research project also provided training and professional development opportunities for both undergraduate and graduate students on methodologies in educational research, including the completion of a master’s thesis and doctoral dissertation. Dissemination of findings include multiple poster presentations and invited conference presentations at national education conferences including SABER, Gordon Research Conference, SEISMIC. Further, peer-reviewed manuscripts detailing our findings are in progress for publication at leading educational journals. Ultimately, continuation of this work, including scaling up SL-CUREs and further assessment of the impact on diverse student populations is planned, with the goal of broadening participation and inclusion to strengthen the STEM workforce by bringing a wide range of perspectives and ideas necessary to tackle complex scientific and technological challenges.
